text:
Folks, do a little research instead of just falling for a pol because he seems pleasant and seems reasonable.  Like every current member of the GOP, Kasich is a menace.  His reverence for Ronnie is big red flag, btw.
        He's far right of center but is seen as a moderate : 'The Guardian reports that Kasich is sometimes "billed as a moderate" due to his "unassuming image," but has a record in the House and as Ohio governor that "puts him a big step to the right of what many Americans would consider in the middle." Larry Sabato, the director of the University of Virginia Center for Politics, who has known Kasich for years, says that "If you had asked me in the 90s about Kasich I would have said he was a Gingrich conservative." '

         He opposes abortion, he favors the Keystone pipeline, he supports for-profit prisons, he opposes legalization of recreational and medical marijuana (showing that he doesn't understand how many lives the black market is claiming); he opposed the estate tax (which aplies only to those with $5 mil or more) and supports an increase in the sales tax (which hurts the poor and middle-class). And the list of bad policies -- policies that hurt ordinary Americans -- goes on.

text: He didn't sound like a Republican at first, but then he put all the responsibility on the people, insisting they have to go to extreme measures just to get reasonable legislation passed. His take on gerrymandering? Spot on. The environment, health care, gun control, exactly right. But his assumption that things that were will necessarily lead to things that will be is seriously flawed and designed to hide the issue of where Republican power comes from. It's not from grassroots activists if you need a hint, more along the lines of how the Tea Party was founded. And for all his enthusiastic and encouraging rhetoric, his explanation of gerrymandering off the top simply undermines his entire point. Politicians know they can win on the right, even if they get fewer votes because it's ultimately broken down into districts and the Republicans know they have more of the districts, with fewer people, than the Democrats do. Not to mention, does he remember civil rights well? People died, at the hands of neighbors, law enforcement, and assassination. Is that the kind of confidence he's asking people to have? The fight for civil rights prior lead to the Civil War... is that what he thinks should happen again? There were lots of nice words, but he never put the responsibility for morals and common good on the people who were elected to do those exact things. Instead it was if these things aren't getting done it's all your fault, with a smile and positive energy. Seemingly saying one thing, but meaning the opposite? That's a Republican.

text: Yes...America is the world's richest country. However, most of that wealth is tied up in personal fortunes unavailable for the common good. For example, the combined wealth of the Walton, Koch, and Mars families is more than the combined wealth of 4 million American families of median wealth. And...their wealth has increased over 6000% since 1982, while the wealth of a median income US family decreased by 3% over the same time period. Consider as a further example of the 'insulation' of this wealth that Jeff Bezos, Warren Buffet, and Bill Gates, the three wealthiest people in the world, are wealthier than the bottom half of the country ‚Äî combined. And since much of their wealth is 'unrealized' for the purpose of taxation, that America is cash poor, dependent on the tax revenues of a citizenry whose income has stagnated. Average pre-tax incomes for the bottom 50% of wage earners, when adjusted for inflation was $16,000 in 1980. More than 30 years later, it was $16,200. So as a nation, how rich are we when so much of that wealth is unavailable to be used for things like health care, infrastructure, etc?
